reviewText: Kate and Allie is a great buddy comedy. It had heart. It was not Lucy or Laverne & Shirley--it was character driven by human emotion and a love of family. It was a sitcom above the restWhat ticks me off is the high price for SIX (yes 6 ) Episodes. Somebody lined their pockets on this DVD release-Hopefully someone will re-release these six with season twoIts worth five stars, but if is was more of a price break, i would rate it higherBennet Pomerantz, AUDIOWORLD
summary: Too Much for ONLY SIX Episodes

reviewText: I remember watching this show religously when it first aired.  I loved everything about it, the characters, the actors, the writing and the situations.  Thankfully, watching this DVD I experienced the same joy and entertainment I did upon my firt viewings all those years ago.Sure the show is dated but the comedy and situations are universal and timeless.  If you're a sit-com fan who's never seen Kate & Allie before, you're in for a big treat.This single DVD has all six episodes of the show's first season plus one episode from season 2.  You also get a short documentary featuring Susan Sait James and the show's creator talking about making the show.  Also included on the disc is a very fun half hour or so documentary about other shows that were on the 1980's.  It was a real nostalgia trip to see all these old shows.  I'm sure to watch this almost as much as the shows themselves.  A cute bloopers reel is also on the disc.Overall this is a great start to enjoying Kate & Allie on DVD.  Only trouble is that this single DVD is priced too high.  Something is wrong when you can get a full season of other shows for just five dollars more than what this single disc is going for.

reviewText: I consider Jane Curtain one of the funniest actresses of all time.  From her early work on "Saturday Night Live", to her later work on "Third Rock from the Sun", to "Kate and Allie" in between, Jane Curtain can do no wrong in my eyes.On "Kate and Allie", she plays Allie, while Susan Saint James plays Kate.  Together, they play a couple of best friends who live together post-divorce and raise their kids together.  Although these two are best friends, they're very different in temperament and aspirations.  Each episode reveals their differences.In episode 1, Allie goes on her first date post-divorce.  Here we learn these women's differences in self-esteem.  Kate is a very confident woman in both her beauty and sexuality, while Allie is more timid and unsure of herself.  Here we also discover Allie's competitiveness with Kate, which will come up later in the season, too.In episode 2, Kate's daughter makes a school video of the family interacting with one another as a way to show how divorce impacts families.  Here we discover the two women's differing parenting styles.  Allie pushes her kids towards achieving excellence, while Kate is more laid back and content with her daughter being a C-student.  However, in this episode, Allie influences Kate to push a little harder and expect a little more from her daughter.  We also learn what kind of father Kate's ex-husband is.In episode 3, Allie's son gets beat up by a bully.  Here we discover more about the differences in parenting style, plus how having a split family impacts the children.  In episode 2, we learned what kind of father Kate's ex-husband was, and in episode 3, we learn what kind of father Allie's ex-husband is.In episode 4, Allie starts her own home-based cake making business.  Here we discover these women's differences in career aspirations.  Kate is career-minded and wants to climb the latter, while Allie has always believed a women's place is to stay home and be taken care of by a man.  However, Kate influences Allie to push herself out of her comfort zone.In episode 5, Allie starts to add more of her stuff (actually a lot of her stuff) into Kate's home, whom her and her kids have moved into.  Here we learn their differences in style plus how challenging it is to move two different tastes into one living space.In episode 6, Kate spends a weekend alone with her ex-husband while Allie is left home alone for the first time in her life.  Here we discover their differences in being independent and we also learn more about Kate's marriage to her ex.Both of these women are funny, but it's really Curtain who gave me the most laughs, and there were some laugh out loud moments in this series.  Although this show is commentary on divorce, because it's a comedy, things are kept pretty light and always a happy ending.  This show aired during the 80's and it's evident by Kate's bright clothing.  What's funny, though, is that some things Kate wears are back in style today!Overall, I enjoy this show because it's funny and fun to watch.
summary: Just when you think you're all by yourself, you're not

reviewText: I just watched an ep from this series which was included on the "Gimme A Break" Season One set and I loved it. I don't remember watching this show growing up. It is a great show though because it presents another type of family and proves that family comes in different forms. "Kate & Allie" reminds me of "The Golden Girls" or "The Facts Of Life." Like other reviewers, I plan to buy the Canadian set next month. Not because I think the US release is a rip-off, but because I want to see as many episodes of this awesome series as I can because it is very realistic and poignant.Here's all the season one eps w/ descriptions & original air dates:Allie's First Date / March 19, 1984Newly divorced Allie Lowell gets asked out on her first date since college and doesn't know how to deal with it.The Very Loud Family / March 26, 1984When the kids are assigned a class project to show "change", Emmamakes a video on her family. This ep is included on the "Gimme A Break" Season One set.Odd Boy Out / April 16, 1984Allie discovers that Chip's friends think he's a sissy because of his upbringing.The Family Business / April 23, 1984After Kate gets a promotion at the travel agency, Allie starts to feel she may have missed out on life's rewards.Dear Diary / April 30, 1984Kate's curiosity gets the best of her when she finds Allie's diary.A Weekend to Remember / May 7, 1984Allie finds herself alone when Kate goes on a ski trip with her ex-husband and the kids are off doing their own thing.
summary: A timeless sitcom that is very underrated

reviewText: Although this was one of my favorite television shows growing up, I have to say it isn't worth the money...at least not in this format.I didn't remember until I actually bought this DVD that Kate & Allie was a midseason replacement. Therefore, "Season 1" actually has only six episodes. As a "bonus," they toss in two Season 2 episodes; but it feels less like something given gratis and more like something thrown in to placate the fans sitting around going, "Huh? That's IT?"Perhaps a better idea would have been to sell Seasons 1 and 2 together, much like "Facts of Life." While the latter had two complete seasons, Season 1 included a too-large cast - most of whom were not asked to return for Season 2 - and probably would not have been bought by too many fans of the show. That way, both seasons were purchased, and yet fans could feel they were getting their money's worth.
summary: A great show, but grossly mispackaged...

reviewText: Little did I know when ordering that I was ordering only 6 episodes.  The First Season had only 6 episodes because the show wasn't "picked up" until 2/3 of the way through the season!  I guess that's why the price was so low.  Good show--good writing, but I don't think it has the vast appeal of classics like I Love Lucy, Seinfeld and even The Brady Bunch, which I still watch to this day!  Great 80's clothes and great talented ladies (Jane Curtin and Susan Saint James) make this worthy of taking a look--plus guest-starring roles of people that went on to "bigger and better things!"

reviewText: I first watched K and A about 20 years ago. It instantly became my favourite sitcom offering a unique mix of domestic warmth and sharp punchy humour. After so many yrs during which I've been hooked by more modern productions such as Will and Grace, The Office, Scrubs, Friends and their likes, I still find K and A right up there with the best of them. It hasn't lost a step. SSJ and JC are incredible with their comic timing and delivery. They are like 2 very good friends of mine who are cuttingly witty and yet caring in their hearts. Humour without the cynicism. I recommend it to all sitcom lovers. I agree with some reviewers that 6 episodes are a bit scanty for a full priced DVD. But in Hong Kong, it retails at a discounted rate compared to other sitcoms on full length DVD. Don't know whether that's a reflection of the half sized content of K and A's or it's relative anonymity in Hong Kong.

reviewText: Kate and Allie was the great woman's comedy of the 80's.  This was the first great women dominated series since Mary Tyler Moore in the 1970's.Kate and Ally were two divocees that are sharing an apartment in NYC.  They could not make ends meet on their own and also could use each other for moral support.Kate McCardle(Susan St. James) was married to an actor and has a daugter, Emma (Ari Meyers).  Therefore, she always supported her family.Allie Lowell (Jane Curtin - just after SNL) was married to a doctor who dumped her for a newer model.  She has two kids Jennie (Allison Smith - a former Broadway Little Orpan Annie)and Chip (Frederick Koehler).Each episode dealt with the girls dealing with making ends meet or a child's crisis.  This was one of the best written series of the 80's.This also proved that Jane Curtin had more to her than Saturday Night Live skits.  This also was Susan St. James' first hit since MacMillan and Wife.I call this a woman's series but it is not for women.  Eveyone will enjoy the wity dialog and the true to life situations that the show dealt with.THIS IS A DEFINITE MUST HAVE SERIES!!NOTE: I just discovered that this has just six episodes.  And they are the syndicated version.  The thing is that at the end of each show there was a great scene usually between the two stars.  This was a great cap to the episode but in the syndicated version, this was cut out because it was an addition to the show and the show could stand alone but it was that great piece of extra that made the series special.
summary: Jane and Jill create two Great Ladies

reviewText: I enjoyed watching the first six episodes of "Kate & Allie" plus the gratis Season 2 episode where Allie goes to college, only to cheat on a science test.  Unfortunately, NBC Universal should have packaged both Season 1 with Season 2 of "Kate & Allie" plus included bonus features, such as commentaries; a blooper reel; two documentaries--one on the making of the series and the other on Kate & Allie's New York; and perhaps even an original script or two.  They could have even included an episode of the never-aired Filmation animated series--"Not In Our Backyard"--in which Ted constructs a homemade spaceship behind the girls' apartment.  Instead, all we get is a one-disc album of seven episodes that was severely overpriced and has now found its way to Big Lots, where it can be purchased for three bucks.  What a travesty.
summary: Great Show, But A Major Marketing Ripoff

reviewText: I remember watching this show often but not every week growing up. And while I liked it it lacked something. Watching season 1 again all these years later I think I figured out what it was missing . . . or better yet what it had. It was too real. Too uncomfortably real. Kids of divorce wanting to live with the other parent but can't. Dads not showing up because of work and disappointing the kids. Kids being shuttled between one house and the other. Adults cheating and almost getting expelled. Etc. All good stuff don't get me wrong. And people being people. Admirable people trying to do the right thing and being human and failing here and there. But honestly I like escapism in entertainment . . . it is after all entertainment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This abbreviated season of this awesome sitcom introduced a new type of nuclear family to the 1980s: a pair of divorced women living with their children together in a somewhat cramped New York brownstone.This mid-season replacement in the Spring of 1984 starring Susan Saint James as Kate McArdle and Jane Curtain as Allie Lowell was both a critical and commercial success. The shoulder pads, clunky answering machine, and hairdon'ts give away the decade, but the storylines of grown-up best friends supporting and, at times, sparring with each other during personal and professional crises are timeless.Curtain and Saint James share a wonderful chemistry that makes them easy to watch. At the start of this sitcom that ran on CBS from 1984-89, viewers are introduced to Allie's first post-divorce date, played by a dashing young Kelsey Grammer from CHERRS & FRASIER.Almost 2 decades before the gals on SEX & THE CITY  began tackling relationships, Kate summed it up best: "Dating's about finding someone so you never have to date again." By the time CBS cancelled KATE & ALLIE in the Spring of 1989, Kate and Allie's relationship had gotten a little hackneyed & stale and it was time for the ladies to move on. But those first few seasons were fast, funny, and full of possibilities since the show was still in its honeymoon phase, but perhaps the whole cast & crew of the show was getting tired & the show was running out of steam.

If this is too much for you and you cannot find the disc on sale somewhere, then don't buy it, but don't come crying when this disc is out of print and no other seasons are available- Look at Malcolm in the Middle- so far only one season out.  Besides, it really is not much more cost-wise than a single movie.

reviewText: "Kate & Allie" debuted as a mid-season replacement in spring 1984.  The show's first six episodes, which comprise this first season disk, were an immediate hit (#8 for the season and an Emmy nomination for Best Comedy Series), and the series continued for another five seasons.  The series repaired Susan St. James ("McMillan and Wife") as Kate and Jane Curtin ("Saturday Night Live") as Allie - the two had starred in the largely forgotten 1980 movie, "How to Beat the High Co$t of Living" (which also featured Jessica Lange).  Kate and Allie are both mothers who have been best friends since childhood.  Kate has been divorced for awhile, and when Allie's successful physician husband divorces her, she and Kate decide to move in together and start a new life.  Kate works at a travel agency, while life-long housewife Allie stays home and takes care of the house and kids.I watched "Kate & Allie" regularly as a teen when it was on the air.  Since then, it has rarely been in syndication, especially when compared to other hit comedies of the era.  Frankly, time hasn't been particularly kind to the show.  The first six episodes contain a few laughs, but the show is clearly still trying to find its footing.  The acting is so-so, with Susan St. James coming off best as free-spirited Kate.  Jane Curtin (who won two consecutive Emmys for Lead Actress in a Comedy, beating St. James in the process) seems shrill today, and her character is simply not endearing.  Likewise, Kate's daughter (Emma played by Ari Meyers) comes off much more naturally than Allie's two kids (Allison Smith as Jennie and Frederick Koehler as Chip), who mug for the camera and step on every line.  However, the series still is worthwhile for its warm depiction of adult female friends who pitch in to help each other.  Most people can only dream of having a friend like Kate or Allie.  I would have given it 4 stars, but this DVD set has become outdated by the subsequent release of a set featuring both Seasons 1 and 2.  The set really isn't worth buying for six skimpy shows.
summary: "Just when you think you're all by yourself, you're not."
